#Text=M'SIEU FORTIER'S VIOLIN

#Text=Slowly , one by one , the lights in the French Opera go out , until there is but a single glimmer of pale yellow flickering in the great dark space , a few moments ago all a-glitter with jewels and the radiance of womanhood and a-clash with music .
#Text=Darkness now , and silence , and a great haunted hush over all , save for the distant cheery voice of a stage hand humming a bar of the opera .
#Text=The glimmer of gas makes a halo about the bowed white head of a little old man putting his violin carefully away in its case with aged , trembling , nervous fingers .
#Text=Old M'sieu Fortier was the last one out every night .
#Text=Outside the air was murky , foggy . Gas and electricity were but faint splotches of light on the thick curtain of fog and mist .

#Text=Around the opera was a mighty bustle of carriages and drivers and footmen , with a car gaining headway in the street now and then , a howling of names and numbers , the laughter and small talk of cloaked society stepping slowly to its carriages , and the more bourgeoisie vocalisation of the foot passengers who streamed along and hummed little bits of music .

#Text=The fog 's denseness was confusing , too , and at one moment it seemed that the little narrow street would become inextricably choked and remain so until some mighty engine would blow the crowd into atoms .
#Text=It had been a crowded night .

#Text=From around Toulouse Street , where led the entrance to the troisiemes , from the grand stairway , from the entrance to the quatriemes , the human stream poured into the street , nearly all with a song on their lips .
#Text=M'sieu Fortier stood at the corner , blinking at the beautiful ladies in their carriages .

#Text=He exchanged a hearty salutation with the saloon-keeper at the corner , then , tenderly carrying his violin case , he trudged down Bourbon Street , a little old , bent , withered figure , with shoulders shrugged up to keep warm , as though the faded brown overcoat were not thick enough .
#Text=Down on Bayou Road , not so far from Claiborne Street , was a house , little and old and queer , but quite large enough to hold M'sieu Fortier , a wrinkled dame , and a white cat .

#Text=He was home but little , for on nearly every day there were rehearsals ; then on Tuesday , Thursday , and Saturday nights , and twice Sundays there were performances , so Ma'am Jeanne and the white cat kept house almost always alone .
#Text=Then , when M'sieu Fortier was at home , why , it was practice , practice all the day , and smoke , snore , sleep at night .
#Text=Altogether it was not very exhilarating .
#Text=M'sieu Fortier had played first violin in the orchestra ever since -- well , no one remembered his not playing there .
#Text=Sometimes there would come breaks in the seasons , and for a year the great building would be dark and silent .
#Text=Then M'sieu Fortier would do jobs of playing here and there , one night for this ball , another night for that soiree dansante , and in the day , work at his trade , -- that of a cigar-maker .
#Text=But now for seven years there had been no break in the season , and the little old violinist was happy .
#Text=There is nothing sweeter than a regular job and good music to play , music into which one can put some soul , some expression , and which one must study to understand .
#Text=Dance music , of the frivolous , frothy kind deemed essential to soirees , is trivial , easy , uninteresting .
#Text=So M'sieu Fortier , Ma'am Jeanne , and the white cat lived a peaceful , uneventful existence out on Bayou Road .
#Text=When the opera season was over in February , M'sieu went back to cigar-making , and the white cat purred none the less contentedly .
#Text=It had been a benefit to-night for the leading tenor , and he had chosen " Roland a Ronceveaux , " a favourite this season , for his farewell .
#Text=And , mon Dieu , mused the little M'sieu , but how his voice had rung out bell-like , piercing above the chorus of the first act !
#Text=Encore after encore was given , and the bravos of the troisiemes were enough to stir the most sluggish of pulses .
#Text=" Superbes Pyrenees Qui dressez dans le ciel , Vos cimes couronnees D'un hiver eternelle , Pour nous livrer passage Ouvrez vos larges flancs , Faites faire l'orage , Voici , venir les Francs !

#Text=M'sieu quickened his pace down Bourbon Street as he sang the chorus to himself in a thin old voice , and then , before he could see in the thick fog , he had run into two young men .

#Text= I -- I -- beg your pardon , -- messieurs , " he stammered .

column1: #Text=" Most certainly , " was the careless response ; then the speaker , taking a second glance at the object of the rencontre , cried joyfully :
#Text=" Oh , M'sieu Fortier , is it you ?
